story:
SHOOTING HOOPS: HELP GET MY UNIQUE PHOTO COLLECTION DISPLAYED AT MADISON SQUARE GARDEN

A story of basketball obsession

Shooting Hoops is a quest to get my photo's of New York City basketball hoops displayed at the sports spiritual home - Madison Square Garden.

My dream is to have the world's most famous arena display my unique photo collection under the slogan "Over 700 courts in New York City.  Only ONE Madison Square Garden."

Who/What/Why???

My name is Thai Neave.  I'm a former ESPN International SportsCenter Host who is combining my passion for photography with my love of basketball in New York City. 

After playing basketball since I was 12 years old, I started to look at hoops a little differently when I arrived in New York City to begin my position with ESPN.  I discovered that there was much more to a hoop than a cylinder ring and a rectangle backboard.  In fact, the more I found and looked and wandered aimlessly through Manhattan with my camera, the more I realized that each one had a distinct and beautiful life of its own.

My compulsive journey has taken me down nearly every street in Manhattan and after 18 months - through rain and snow and almost getting arrested on numerous occassions - I've amassed a rather unique collection.  From hoops that sprout out of vivid graffiti, to rusted rings that are nestled under the canopy of Manhattan buildings, to dilapidated basketball courts where you would least expect them, each image gives a distinct perspective of my favorite city in the world:  The seasons change, people come and go, buildings and skyscrapers emerge, but the hoops remain proudly untouched, anchored to the concrete, awaiting nothing more than a ball to play with.    

Now the time has come to share SHOOTING HOOPS with the city, and what better place than at Madison Square Garden. 

Beyond this dream, I'm also looking to begin a collaboration with one of the major sporting brands to work on a SHOOTING HOOPS T-Shirt Series and create a coffee table book.

Ultimately this isn't about making money:  SHOOTING HOOPS is about getting what I feel is a unique perspective of New York City on display in the world's most famous and awe inspiring arena.

When???

Before the New York Knicks 2012/2013 regular season.  I need to hustle!

How you can help??? 

If you're an art/photography/basketball/New York City lover then my campaign could really use your help.   

Funding will support with the following:

 

  • Help me remain based in Manhattan to establish contact with marketing/creative directors at Madison Square Garden and continue expanding my SHOOTING HOOPS collection.
  • Pay for the rental of a helicopter to take aerial photos of courts 
  • Attract attention from major sporting brands such as Nike, Adidas, Reebok, Converse for potential Shooting Hoops T-Shirt series
  • Gain attention from NBA stars/Basketball fanatics for installing feature walls of my work (For some reason I've always believed Spike Lee and Steve Nash will want a feature wall in their Manhattan Pads)
  • Attract publishers for coffee table book "Shooting Hoops"
  • Get MOMA to knock on my door for an exhibit (I can dream can't I?! But seriously, I saw a feature wall once in MOMA of different manholes around the city - SHOOTING HOOPS has far greater interest don't you think?)

 

Apart from direct funding: 

I would really love any advice, support, mentoring, contacts, marketing strategies, networking, general help I can get.  

Even if you just think what I'm doing is cool or you want to just say hi, please do.  You don't have to only help out with $$$, by simply sharing this campaign and my video link, you are showing your support.  One thing I have learn't from all the amazing people I have met in New York City is that we can all help pave the way for  creative paths simply through the art of connecting each other.  

What I'll be spending on???

  • Shooting photos of more hoops in greater New York i.e. the Bronx, New Jersey, Brooklyn
  • Rental of helicopter for aerial perspectives
  • Renting ladders for different perspective shots 
  • Working with Graphic Designers for fine art/coffee table book
  • Hiring graphic designers for T-Shirt concepts 
  • Paying for T-shirt samples
  • Printing large format photos for exhibition in Manhattan Gallery (MOMA???)
  • Printing example coffee table books to take to publishers 
If I get MORE than I'm asking for it simply allows more time to shoot hoops in NYC, more opportunities to get in contact with the right people i.e. MSG, NIKE etc, higher quality prints, better graphic designers etc  
 

What You Get???

I would like to my show my gratitude for helping out my campaign by offering you guys some unique perks. Up for grabs is:
 
  • Your own photo print (Choose your favorite hoop) 
  • A coffee table book of my work
  • A feature wall in your home with a collection of your favorite hoops
  • A big fat THANK YOU! 
 

The Impact...

From the thousands of people who play streetball to those that make millions representing the New York Knicks, everyone has at one time or another stared up at a basketball hoop and admired it's simplicity.  Now it's time to show the world that Basketball hoops are as part of New York City as it's skyscrapers, Time Square, and the Statue of liberty.

Working with Graphic Designers for fine art/coffee table book
Hiring graphic designers for T-Shirt concepts 
Paying for T-shirt samples
Printing large format photos for exhibition in Manhattan Gallery (MOMA???)
Printing example coffee table books to take to publishers 

If I get MORE than I'm asking for it simply allows more time to shoot hoops in NYC, more opportunities to get in contact with the right people i.e. MSG, NIKE etc, higher quality prints, better graphic designers etc  
 
What You Get???
I would like to my show my gratitude for helping out my campaign by offering you guys some unique perks. Up for grabs is:
 


Your own photo print (Choose your favorite hoop) 
A coffee table book of my work
A feature wall in your home with a collection of your favorite hoops
A big fat THANK YOU! 


 
The Impact...
From the thousands of people who play streetball to those that make millions representing the New York Knicks, everyone has at one time or another stared up at a basketball hoop and admired it's simplicity.  Now it's time to show the world that Basketball hoops are as part of New York City as it's skyscrapers, Time Square, and the Statue of liberty.

story:
BENJAMIN PATTERSON – SNEAK REVIEW 
a free-enactment

performances. concert. exhibition. publication.

[deutsche Version siehe unten]

Benjamin Patterson, fluxus pioneer, artist, and musician will turn 80 this year. To celebrate Ben and his work, we are planning a series of events in Berlin as well as a publication.

Our celebration is inspired by a historical event: the SNEAK PREVIEW: fluxus, happenings, environment, poèmes, danses, compositions that took place on July 3rd, 1962 in Paris, a travelling exhibition opening, in which small works by Patterson were presented in Robert Filliou’s Galérie Légitime (which was located in his hat), and a concert that took place later the same evening.

Together with Ben Patterson and a number of his artist friends, we – Bill Dietz, Christian Kesten, and Petra Stegmann – plan to revisit the historical Sneak Preview by turning it into a Sneak Review, including performances of Ben’s pieces and works by other artists dedicated to Ben.

Bill (www.ensemble-zwischentoene.de) and Christian (www.maulwerker.de) are involved with sound and music, and Petra (www.inarcadia.de) is an art historian and curator. We are all based in and around Berlin and are long-time agitators in the fields of experimental music and action art, having presented Fluxus works in performances, concerts, and exhibitions.

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

In order to realise our extra-institutional project, we need your support. Your funding will enable us to realise the publication (printing costs), to document the events, to pay for performance materials, and will supplement the cost of artists’ travel expenses and honoraria. 

In appreciation of your help, we will keep you updated on our project, send you a copy of the publication, and many other wonderful things (please see the list of perks).

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, there are always other ways you can help: Spread the word, let your friends know about our project, and keep your fingers crossed!

BEN PATTERSON 

Ben Patterson was born in Pittsburgh (U.S.) on May 29th, 1934 and lives in Wiesbaden. From 1952 to 1956, he studied music at the University of Michigan. For some time after this, he played double bass in various symphony orchestras. In 1960, he moved to Cologne, where he played an active part in the new music scene associated with Mary Bauermeister's studio. During this time, he wrote pieces such as VARIATIONS FOR DOUBLE-BASS (1961) and PAPER PIECE (1960), which became Fluxus classics and were frequently performed at Fluxus concerts. In 1961, together with Robert Filliou, Patterson exhibited his Puzzle Poems in Paris. In 1962 he took part in all of the crucial early Fluxus events in Wuppertal, Düsseldorf, Paris and Wiesbaden. He returned to the U.S. in 1963, where he initially worked as a librarian and continued to play an active part in Fluxus until 1967, participating in numerous concerts and performances. 

From 1967 to 1988, he withdrew from the art world and during this period worked as a manager and director of various cultural institutions. He took up his art again in 1988 with an exhibition of assemblages in the Emily Harvey Gallery in New York. Since then, he has taken part in numerous exhibitions and performances around the globe. In 2004 Patterson realized a dream that Fluxus-organizer George Maciunas had fostered forty years earlier – a performance-journey through the (at that time) U.S.S.R. To mark his seventieth birthday, he travelled on the Trans-Siberian Railway through Russia, Mongolia and China as far as Japan, with various interim stops and performances. In 2010/2012 the first larger retrospective of Patterson's work Ben Patterson. In the State of Fluxus was shown in Contemporary Arts Museum Houston and Nassauischer Kunstverein Wiesbaden. In 2012 Patterson received the Kulturpreis of the city of Wiesbaden and presided over the acitivities celebrating the fiftieth Fluxus anniversary in the city. Also in 2012 the first comprehensive collection of his scores Ben Patterson. Event Scores was published.

WHO WE ARE

Bill Dietz is a composer and the artistic director of Ensemble Zwischentöne. Since his tenure with Zwischentöne began in 2007, the ensemble has appeared in spaces from the Hamburger Bahnhof in Berlin to the streets of Aarhus, Denmark to the living room of the Sammlung Hoffmann, performing new works by artists such as Marina Rosenfeld, Rolf Julius, and Chris Newman. 

Christian Kesten and Maulwerker have performed many Fluxus concerts - at the Hamburger Bahnhof in Berlin, the Museo Reina Sofia in Madrid, the Fridericianum in Kassel, Vienna's MUMOK, at ZKM in Karlsruhe and many other locations - together with Emmett Williams and Ann Noel (1999-2007), Alison Knowles (2008), and Ben Patterson (2012).

Petra Stegmann has curated the touring exhibitions FLUXUS EAST (Künstlerhaus Bethanien, Berlin; CAC, Vilnius; Bunkier Sztuki, Kraków; Ludwig Museum, Budapest; Kumu, Tallinn; Nikolaj Kunsthal, Copenhagen; Henie Onstad Kunstsenter, Oslo) and "The lunatics are on the loose ..." EUROPEAN FLUXUS FESTIVALS 1962-1977 (Akademie der Künste, Berlin; MOCAK, Kraków; Staatsgalerie Stuttgart) and published widely on Fluxus and action art.

OUR PROGRAM

BENJAMIN PATTERSON – SNEAK REVIEW, performance tour
March 11th, 8 am to 8 pm – city of Berlin
"free-enactment" of the SNEAK PEVIEW that took place in Paris on July 3rd, 1962, now throughout the city of Berlin, featuring micro-performances new and old, organised by Petra Stegmann

CONCERT EXAMINATION
March 11th, 9 pm – Ackerstadtpalast
Ackerstr. 169/170, Berlin-Mitte
Organised by Bill Dietz and Christian Kesten with the participation of Ben Patterson and members of the ensembles Zwischentöne and Maulwerker

DR. BEN'S MEDICINE SHOW
March 14th, 8 pm – SCHAU FENSTER, RAUM FÜR KUNST
Lobeckstr. 30-35, Berlin-Kreuzberg
Fluxus parody, in which Ben Patterson will cure visitors with the help of brain scans and elixirs

BENJAMIN PATTERSON – SNEAK REVIEW, exhibition
March 14th - March 28th – SCHAU FENSTER, RAUM FÜR KUNST
Lobeckstr. 30-35, Berlin-Kreuzberg
Documentation of the March 11th performance tour as well as instructions and ideas by Ben's artist colleagues and friends, curated by Petra Stegmann

BENJAMIN PATTERSON – SNEAK REVIEW, publication
A collection of statements/instructions/ideas/memories by Ben's friends and colleagues (artists and art historians), hand-bound, 136 pages, published by DOWN WITH ART! Verlag, Potsdam


www.sneakreview.tumblr.com
www.facebook.com/downwithartev

Dear supporters,

for this campaign only Paypal can be used as mode of payment.
If you would like to help our project by bank transfer and receive a donation receipt, you can also support us at:

DOWN WITH ART! e.V.
Sparkasse Potsdam, Saarmunder Str. 61, 14478 Potsdam
IBAN  DE48 1605 0000 1000 9244 55
BIC  WELADED1PMB
regarding "SNEAK REVIEW"


BEN PATTERSON – SNEAK REVIEW 

Ein Free-Enactment

Performances. Konzert. Ausstellung. Publikation

Benjamin Patterson, Fluxus-Pionier, Künstler und Musiker wird dieses Jahr 80 Jahre alt. Um Patterson und sein Werk zu feiern, planen wir eine kleine Veranstaltungsreihe in Berlin sowie eine Publikation.

Unser Programm wurde durch ein historisches Ereignis inspiriert: die SNEAK PREVIEW: fluxus, happenings, environment, poèmes, danses, compositions, die am 3. Juli 1962 in Paris stattfand – eine tourende Ausstellungseröffnung, bei der kleine Werke von Ben Patterson in Robert Fillious Galérie Légitime (die sich in seinem Hut befand) präsentiert wurden und die ihren Abschluss mit einem Konzert fand.

Zusammen mit Ben Patterson und einigen seiner Künstlerfreunde planen wir – Bill Dietz, Christian Kesten und Petra Stegmann – an die historische SNEAK PREVIEW anzuknüpfen und sie als eine SNEAK REVIEW zu gestalten, bei der Pattersons Stücke ebenso wie die Arbeiten anderer Künstler, die ihm gewidmet sind, aufgeführt werden.

Bill Dietz (www.ensemble-zwischentoene.de) und Christian Kesten (www.maulwerker.de) beschäftigen sich mit Klang und Musik, Petra Stegmann (www.inarcadia.de) ist Kunsthistorikerin und Kuratorin. Wir leben in Berlin und Potsdam und arbeiten seit langem in den Bereichen experimenteller Musik und Aktionskunst und haben Fluxus-Arbeiten in Performances, Konzerten und Ausstellungen präsentiert.

WAS WIR BRAUCHEN & WIE WIR DANKEN

Um unser institutionell unabhängiges Projekt umsetzen zu können, brauchen wir Ihre Unterstützung, die uns dabei helfen wird, eine Publikation herauszugeben, die Ereignisse zu dokumentieren, für Performance-Materialien zu sorgen und die Kosten für Reise, Aufenthalt und Honorar der Künstler zu ergänzen.

Als Dank für Ihre Hilfe werden wir Sie über den Projektverlauf auf dem Laufenden halten, ein Exemplar der Publikation zusenden und viele andere interessante Dinge anbieten (siehe "ALS DANK" weiter unten).

BEN PATTERSON 

Patterson wurde 1934 in Pittsburgh (USA) geboren und lebt heute in Wiesbaden. Von 1952 bis 1956 studierte er Musik an der University of Michigan. Danach spielte er als Kontrabassist in verschiedenen Symphonie-Orchestern. 1960 zog er nach Köln, wo er eine aktive Rolle in der Neue-Musik-Szene im Umfeld des Ateliers von Mary Bauermeister übernahm. Während dieser Zeit schrieb er auch Stücke wie die VARIATIONS FOR DOUBLE-BASS (1961) und PAPER PIECE (1960), die zu Fluxus-Klassikern wurden und häufig bei Fluxus-Konzerten performt wurden, das letztere bis heute. 1961 stellte Patterson gemeinsam mit Robert Filliou seine Puzzle Poems in Paris aus. 1962 nahm er an allen wichtigen frühen Fluxus-Ereignissen teil wie z.B. Kleines Sommerfest: Après John Cage in Wuppertal, Neo-Dada in der Musik in Düsseldorf, die SNEAK PREVIEW: fluxus, happenings, environement, poèmes, danses, compositions in Paris und die Fluxus-Internationale Festspiele Neuester Musik in Wiesbaden. 1963 kehrte er in die USA zurück, wo er zunächst als Bibliothekar arbeitete und bis 1967 eine aktive Rolle bei Fluxus spielte.

Danach zog er sich bis 1988 von der Kunstwelt zurück und arbeitete als Manager und Direktor verschiedener Kulturinstitutionen. 1988 wurde eine Ausstellung seiner Arbeiten in der Emily Harvey Gallery in New York gezeigt. Seit dieser Zeit nahm er an zahlreichen Ausstellungen und Performances teil. 2004 – zu seinem 70. Geburtstag – reiste er mit der transsibirischen Eisenbahn durch Russland, die Mongolei und China – und erreichte schließlich Japan, mit verschiedenen Zwischenstopps und Performances. 2010 wurde erstmals die größere Retrospektive Ben Patterson. In the State of Fluxus im Contemporary Arts Museum Houston und 2012 im Nassauischen Kunstverein Wiesbaden gezeigt. 2012 erhielt er den Kulturpreis der Stadt Wiesbaden und war Pate der Feierlichkeiten zum 50. Jahrestag von Fluxus. Im gleichen Jahr erschien erstmals eine ausführliche Zusammenstellung seiner Partituren Ben Patterson. Event Scores.

WER WIR SIND

Bill Dietz ist Komponist und künstlerischer Leiter des Ensemble Zwischentöne. Seitdem er die Leitung der Zwischentöne 2007 übernahm, trat das Ensemble an sehr unterschiedlichen Orten auf vom Hamburger Bahnhof in Berlin, den Straßen von Aarhus, Dänemark bishin zum Wohnzimmer der Sammlung Hoffmann und performte neue Werke von Künstlern wie Marina Rosenfeld, Rolf Julius und Chris Newman. 

Christian Kesten und die Maulwerker führten eine Reihe von Fluxus-Konzerten auf – im Hamburger Bahnhof, Berlin; Museo Reina Sofia, Madrid; Fridericianum, Kassel; MUMOK, Wien; ZKM, Karlsruhe und an vielen anderen Orten – zusammen mit Emmett Williams und Ann Noël (1999-2007), Alison Knowles (2008) und Ben Patterson (2012).

Petra Stegmann kuratierte die Ausstellungen FLUXUS EAST (Künstlerhaus Bethanien, Berlin; CAC, Vilnius; Bunkier Sztuki, Krakau; Ludwig Museum, Budapest; Kumu, Tallinn; Nikolaj Kunsthal, Copenhagen; Henie Onstad Kunstsenter, Oslo) und "The lunatics are on the loose ..." EUROPEAN FLUXUS FESTIVALS 1962-1977 (u.a. Akademie der Künste, Berlin; MOCAK, Krakau; Staatsgalerie Stuttgart) und veröffentlichte viel über Fluxus und Aktionskunst.

UNSER PROGRAMM

BENJAMIN PATTERSON – SNEAK REVIEW, Performance-Tour 
11. März, 8 bis 20 Uhr – Berliner Innenstadt 
"free-enactment" der SNEAK PEVIEW die am 3. Juli 1962 in Paris stattfand, jetzt im Berliner Stadzentrum mit Mikro-Performances neuer und alter Stücke, organisiert von Petra Stegmann

KONZERT EXAMINATION
11. März, 21 Uhr – Ackerstadtpalast  
Ackerstr. 169/170, Berlin-Mitte 
organisiert von Bill Dietz und Christian Kesten unter Teilnahme von Ben Patterson und Mitgliedern der Ensembles Zwischentöne und Maulwerker

DR. BEN'S MEDICINE SHOW 
14. März, 20 Uhr – SCHAU FENSTER, RAUM FÜR KUNST 
Lobeckstr. 30-35, Berlin-Kreuzberg 
Fluxus-Parodie, in der Ben Patterson Besucher der Performance mittels Gehirnscan und Elixieren heilen wird

BENJAMIN PATTERSON – SNEAK REVIEW, Ausstellung 
14. März – 28. März – SCHAU FENSTER, RAUM FÜR KUNST 
Lobeckstr. 30-35, Berlin-Kreuzberg 
Dokumentation der Performance-Tour vom 11. März sowie Instruktionen und Ideen von Pattersons Künstlerkollegen und Freunden, kuratiert von Petra Stegmann

BENJAMIN PATTERSON – SNEAK REVIEW, Publikation 
Eine Sammlung von Statements/Instruktionen/Ideen/Erinnerungen von Pattersons Freunden und Kollegen, handgebunden, ca. 130 Seiten, veröffentlicht bei DOWN WITH ART! Verlag, Potsdam

ALS DANK!

5 € VIELEN DANK!

Vielen Dank für Ihre Unterstützung! Alle Beiträge helfen, unsere Pläne zu verwirklichen. Wenn Sie möchten, nehmen wir Sie in unsere Mailingliste auf und veröffentlichen Ihren Namen auf der Projektwebsite. 

10 € EXKLUSIVE PERFORMANCE-BILDER

Vielen Dank für Ihre Hilfe! Wir werden Ihren Namen auf der Projektwebsite veröffentlichen und Sie über das Projekt auf dem Laufenden halten (wenn Sie mögen). Außerdem erhalten Sie eine Dankes-Email mit exklusiven Performance-Bildern (als pdf-Datei) sowie Links zur Online-Dokumentation. 

35 € DER KATALOG

Sie erhalten den Katalog BENJAMIN PATTERSON – SNEAK REVIEW mit Beiträgen von Ben Patterson und vielen anderen (Eric Andersen, Chloe Bass, Philip Corner, Geoffrey Hendricks, Kiwa, Alison Knowles, Jarosław Kozłowski, Mitch McEwen, Larry Miller, Ann Noël, Tamas St.Turba, Aslı Sungu; sowie Texten von Valerie Cassel Oliver, Jon Hendricks, Jan Kage, Astrit Schmidt-Burkhardt u.v.a.). Handgebunden, ca. 130 Seiten. Wir werden Ihnen auch auf unserer Website danken und Sie auf unsere Mailingliste setzen, wenn Sie mögen. 

50 € KATALOG UND DOKUMENTATION

Sie erhalten den Katalog (siehe oben) sowie eine exklusive Performance-Dokumentation der Ereignisse vom 11. und 14. März. Außerdem danken wir Ihnen auf unserer Website und setzen Sie auf die Mailingliste, wenn Sie mögen.

100 € KATALOG UND FLUXUS-PUBLIKATION

Sie erhalten ein Exemplar des Katalogs BENJAMIN PATTERSON – SNEAK REVIEW mit zusätzlicher Performance-Dokumentation und ENTWEDER ein Exemplar des Buchs  "The lunatics are on the loose ..." EUROPEAN FLUXUS FESTIVALS 1962-1977, das ausführliche Dokumentation der Arbeiten Pattersons und seiner Fluxus-Kollegen der 1960er und 1970er Jahre enthält ODER eine DVD-Dokumentation (2 DVDs) unserer Events. Wir werden Ihnen ebenso auf unserer Website danken und setzen Sie auf die Mailingliste, wenn Sie mögen.

150 € EINE ÜBERRASCHUNG!

Sie erhalten eine Überraschung. Was können wir nicht sagen, sonst wäre es keine Überraschung.

250 € IHR NAME IM KATALOG

Ihr Name wird im Katalog gedruckt, den Sie auch erhalten. Außerdem wird Ihnen eine Performance während der SNEAK REVIEW TOUR gewidmet.

500 € PERFORMANCE FÜR SIE

Bitte senden Sie Vorschläge oder Ideen für eine Performance. Wir werden diese mit den Teilnehmern der SNEAK REVIEW TOUR besprechen und Ihnen die daraus resultierende Performance (11. März) widmen. Sie erhalten außerdem eine spezielle Dokumentation der Events zusammen mit dem Katalog.

1000 € EDITION FÜR SAMMLER

Einmalige Edition als Schachtel mit: Katalog BENJAMIN PATTERSON – SNEAK REVIEW, Foto-Dokumentation (50 Fotografien der Ereignisse), 4 DVDs (der Performance-Tour; des Konzerts; Dr. Ben's Medicine Show; Ausstellungsdokumentation), kleine Performance-Relikte (jede Schachtel wird unterschiedlich sein) und weitere Überraschungen. Darüber hinaus seltene Poster der Ausstellungen "Fluxus East", "Fluxus Today" und "Die Irren sind los ..." sowie Katalog "The lunatics are on the loose ..." EUROPEAN FLUXUS FESTIVALS 1962-1977. Die Sammler-Edition ist auf 10 Exemplare limitiert, sie wird nummeriert und signiert. 


www.sneakreview.tumblr.com
www.facebook.com/downwithartev


Liebe Unterstützer,

leider steht uns als Zahlungsweise für diese Kampagne nur Paypal zur Verfügung. 
Wer das Projekt durch Überweisung direkt unterstützen und für seinen finanziellen Beitrag eine steuerlich absetzbare Zuwendungsbestätigung erhalten möchte, kann gerne überweisen an:

DOWN WITH ART! e.V.
Sparkasse Potsdam
IBAN  DE48 1605 0000 1000 9244 55
BIC  WELADED1PMB
Stichwort: SNEAK REVIEW

BRAUCHEN & WIE WIR DANKEN
Um unser
institutionell unabhängiges Projekt umsetzen zu können, brauchen wir Ihre Unterstützung, die uns dabei helfen wird, eine Publikation herauszugeben, die
Ereignisse zu dokumentieren, für Performance-Materialien zu sorgen und die Kosten für Reise, Aufenthalt und Honorar der Künstler zu ergänzen.
Als Dank für
Ihre Hilfe werden wir Sie über den Projektverlauf auf dem Laufenden halten,
ein Exemplar der Publikation zusenden und viele andere interessante Dinge anbieten (siehe "ALS DANK" weiter unten).

BEN
PATTERSON 
Patterson
wurde 1934 in Pittsburgh (USA) geboren und lebt heute in Wiesbaden. Von 1952
bis 1956 studierte er Musik an der University of Michigan. Danach spielte er
als Kontrabassist in verschiedenen Symphonie-Orchestern. 1960 zog er nach Köln,
wo er eine aktive Rolle in der Neue-Musik-Szene im Umfeld des Ateliers von Mary
Bauermeister übernahm. Während dieser Zeit schrieb er auch Stücke wie die VARIATIONS FOR DOUBLE-BASS (1961) und PAPER PIECE (1960), die zu
Fluxus-Klassikern wurden und häufig bei Fluxus-Konzerten performt wurden, das
letztere bis heute. 1961 stellte Patterson gemeinsam mit Robert Filliou seine
Puzzle Poems in Paris aus. 1962 nahm er an allen wichtigen frühen
Fluxus-Ereignissen teil wie z.B. Kleines
Sommerfest: Après John Cage in Wuppertal, Neo-Dada in der Musik in Düsseldorf, die SNEAK PREVIEW: fluxus, happenings, environement, poèmes, danses,
compositions in Paris und die Fluxus-Internationale
Festspiele Neuester Musik in Wiesbaden. 1963 kehrte er in die USA zurück,
wo er zunächst als Bibliothekar arbeitete und bis 1967 eine aktive Rolle bei
Fluxus spielte. 
Danach zog
er sich bis 1988 von der Kunstwelt zurück und arbeitete als Manager und
Direktor verschiedener Kulturinstitutionen. 1988 wurde eine Ausstellung seiner
Arbeiten in der Emily Harvey Gallery in New York gezeigt. Seit dieser Zeit nahm
er an zahlreichen Ausstellungen und Performances teil. 2004 – zu seinem 70.
Geburtstag – reiste er mit der transsibirischen Eisenbahn durch Russland, die
Mongolei und China – und erreichte schließlich Japan, mit verschiedenen
Zwischenstopps und Performances. 2010 wurde erstmals die größere Retrospektive Ben Patterson. In the State of Fluxus im
Contemporary Arts Museum Houston und 2012 im Nassauischen Kunstverein Wiesbaden
gezeigt. 2012 erhielt er den Kulturpreis der Stadt Wiesbaden und war Pate der
Feierlichkeiten zum 50. Jahrestag von Fluxus. Im gleichen Jahr erschien
erstmals eine ausführliche Zusammenstellung seiner Partituren Ben Patterson. Event Scores.
WER WIR SIND
Bill Dietz ist
Komponist und künstlerischer Leiter des Ensemble Zwischentöne. Seitdem er die
Leitung der Zwischentöne 2007 übernahm, trat das Ensemble an sehr
unterschiedlichen Orten auf vom Hamburger Bahnhof in Berlin, den Straßen von
Aarhus, Dänemark bishin zum Wohnzimmer der Sammlung Hoffmann und performte neue
Werke von Künstlern wie Marina Rosenfeld, Rolf Julius und Chris Newman. 
Christian
Kesten und die Maulwerker führten eine Reihe von Fluxus-Konzerten auf – im
Hamburger Bahnhof, Berlin; Museo Reina Sofia, Madrid; Fridericianum, Kassel; MUMOK,
Wien; ZKM, Karlsruhe und an vielen anderen Orten – zusammen mit Emmett
Williams und Ann Noël (1999-2007), Alison Knowles (2008) und Ben Patterson
(2012).
Petra
Stegmann kuratierte die Ausstellungen FLUXUS EAST (Künstlerhaus Bethanien,
Berlin; CAC, Vilnius; Bunkier Sztuki, Krakau; Ludwig Museum, Budapest; Kumu,
Tallinn; Nikolaj Kunsthal, Copenhagen; Henie Onstad Kunstsenter, Oslo) und
"The lunatics are on the loose ..." EUROPEAN FLUXUS FESTIVALS
1962-1977 (u.a. Akademie der Künste, Berlin; MOCAK, Krakau; Staatsgalerie Stuttgart)
und veröffentlichte viel über Fluxus und Aktionskunst.
UNSER
PROGRAMM
BENJAMIN PATTERSON
– SNEAK REVIEW,
Performance-Tour 
11. März, 8 bis 20 Uhr – Berliner Innenstadt 
"free-enactment" der SNEAK PEVIEW die am 3. Juli 1962 in Paris
stattfand, jetzt im Berliner Stadzentrum mit Mikro-Performances neuer und alter
Stücke, organisiert von Petra Stegmann
KONZERT EXAMINATION
11. März, 21 Uhr – Ackerstadtpalast  
Ackerstr. 169/170, Berlin-Mitte 
organisiert von Bill Dietz und Christian Kesten unter Teilnahme von Ben
Patterson und Mitgliedern der Ensembles Zwischentöne und Maulwerker
DR. BEN'S
MEDICINE SHOW 
14. März, 20 Uhr – SCHAU FENSTER, RAUM FÜR KUNST 
Lobeckstr. 30-35, Berlin-Kreuzberg 
Fluxus-Parodie, in der Ben Patterson Besucher der Performance mittels
Gehirnscan und Elixieren heilen wird 
BENJAMIN PATTERSON
– SNEAK REVIEW, Ausstellung 
14. März – 28. März – SCHAU FENSTER, RAUM FÜR KUNST 
Lobeckstr. 30-35, Berlin-Kreuzberg 
Dokumentation der Performance-Tour vom 11. März sowie Instruktionen und Ideen
von Pattersons Künstlerkollegen und Freunden, kuratiert von Petra Stegmann
BENJAMIN PATTERSON
– SNEAK REVIEW, Publikation 
Eine Sammlung von Statements/Instruktionen/Ideen/Erinnerungen von Pattersons Freunden
und Kollegen, handgebunden, ca. 130 Seiten, veröffentlicht bei DOWN WITH
ART! Verlag, Potsdam
ALS DANK!5 € VIELEN DANK!
Vielen Dank für Ihre Unterstützung! Alle Beiträge helfen, unsere Pläne zu verwirklichen. Wenn Sie möchten, nehmen wir Sie in unsere Mailingliste auf und veröffentlichen Ihren Namen auf der Projektwebsite. 10 € EXKLUSIVE PERFORMANCE-BILDER
Vielen Dank für Ihre Hilfe! Wir werden Ihren Namen auf der Projektwebsite veröffentlichen und Sie über das Projekt auf dem Laufenden halten (wenn Sie mögen). Außerdem erhalten Sie eine Dankes-Email mit exklusiven Performance-Bildern (als pdf-Datei) sowie Links zur Online-Dokumentation. 35 € DER KATALOG
Sie erhalten den Katalog BENJAMIN PATTERSON – SNEAK REVIEW mit Beiträgen von Ben Patterson und vielen anderen (Eric Andersen, Chloe Bass, Philip Corner, Geoffrey Hendricks, Kiwa, Alison Knowles, Jarosław Kozłowski, Mitch McEwen, Larry Miller, Ann Noël, Tamas St.Turba, Aslı Sungu; sowie Texten von Valerie Cassel Oliver, Jon Hendricks, Jan Kage, Astrit Schmidt-Burkhardt u.v.a.). Handgebunden, ca. 130 Seiten. Wir werden Ihnen auch auf unserer Website danken und Sie auf unsere Mailingliste setzen, wenn Sie mögen. 50 € KATALOG UND DOKUMENTATION
Sie erhalten den Katalog (siehe oben) sowie eine exklusive Performance-Dokumentation der Ereignisse vom 11. und 14. März. Außerdem danken wir Ihnen auf unserer Website und setzen Sie auf die Mailingliste, wenn Sie mögen.100 € KATALOG UND FLUXUS-PUBLIKATION
Sie erhalten ein Exemplar des Katalogs BENJAMIN PATTERSON – SNEAK REVIEW mit zusätzlicher Performance-Dokumentation und ENTWEDER ein Exemplar des Buchs  "The lunatics are on the loose ..." EUROPEAN FLUXUS FESTIVALS 1962-1977, das ausführliche Dokumentation der Arbeiten Pattersons und seiner Fluxus-Kollegen der 1960er und 1970er Jahre enthält ODER eine DVD-Dokumentation (2 DVDs) unserer Events. Wir werden Ihnen ebenso auf unserer Website danken und setzen Sie auf die Mailingliste, wenn Sie mögen.150 € EINE ÜBERRASCHUNG!
Sie erhalten eine Überraschung. Was können wir nicht sagen, sonst wäre es keine Überraschung.250 € IHR NAME IM KATALOG
Ihr Name wird im Katalog gedruckt, den Sie auch erhalten. Außerdem wird Ihnen eine Performance während der SNEAK REVIEW TOUR gewidmet.500 € PERFORMANCE FÜR SIE
Bitte senden Sie Vorschläge oder Ideen für eine Performance. Wir werden diese mit den Teilnehmern der SNEAK REVIEW TOUR besprechen und Ihnen die daraus resultierende Performance (11. März) widmen. Sie erhalten außerdem eine spezielle Dokumentation der Events zusammen mit dem Katalog.1000 € EDITION FÜR SAMMLER
Einmalige Edition als Schachtel mit: Katalog BENJAMIN PATTERSON – SNEAK REVIEW, Foto-Dokumentation (50 Fotografien der Ereignisse), 4 DVDs (der Performance-Tour; des Konzerts; Dr. Ben's Medicine Show; Ausstellungsdokumentation), kleine Performance-Relikte (jede Schachtel wird unterschiedlich sein) und weitere Überraschungen. Darüber hinaus seltene Poster der Ausstellungen "Fluxus East", "Fluxus Today" und "Die Irren sind los ..." sowie Katalog "The lunatics are on the loose ..." EUROPEAN FLUXUS FESTIVALS 1962-1977. Die Sammler-Edition ist auf 10 Exemplare limitiert, sie wird nummeriert und signiert. www.sneakreview.tumblr.comwww.facebook.com/downwithartev
Liebe
Unterstützer,
leider steht
uns als Zahlungsweise für diese Kampagne nur Paypal zur Verfügung. Wer das
Projekt durch Überweisung direkt unterstützen und für seinen finanziellen
Beitrag eine steuerlich absetzbare Zuwendungsbestätigung erhalten möchte, kann gerne überweisen an:
DOWN WITH
ART! e.V.Sparkasse
PotsdamIBAN  DE48 1605 0000 1000 9244 55BIC  WELADED1PMBStichwort:
SNEAK REVIEW

story:
Goal Surpassed!!! Stretch for Dream Theater!

With a forward-thinking $15,000 contribution from our neighbors at Zendesk, we’ve rocketed past our $50,000 goal! Thanks to your support, now we can reach further to make the new CounterPulse a dream for artists and audiences alike. Adding to the Twitter match, the Zendesk contribution marks another endorsement by a local tech company that values space for experimental performing arts in San Francisco.

We’re now past a tipping point. If we carry this forward, we will realize our dream of advancing the technical capacity of our theater by creating a state-of-the-art home for artistic experimentation.

Indiegogo is acting on this exciting news by extending our campaign deadline to midnight on Monday, November 3rd. We now have 4 more days to stretch for upgraded, energy-efficient, adaptable LED lighting equipment for our new theater and studio. Help us get there!

Stretch Perk Unveiled: The Dollhouse Dancer Tote

This limited edition Dollhouse tote pays homage to the former incarnation of our new home at 80 Turk Street, featuring the dancer silhouettes that are currently in the front windows of the building.


You helped us meet the $10,000 Art and Tech Match!

We are beside ourselves with excitement and filled with gratitude that our generous funders have fully met the $10,000 Art and Tech Match pledged by our DJ pals from Honey Soundsystem and our tech-savvy neighbors at Twitter!

This is the kind of collaboration between art and tech that will create the San Francisco we want to live in, where innovation drives our cultural dialogue as well as our technology. And it has brought our goal within reach. Please consider making a contribution and share the news so that we can ride this wave to success!

Assumption Shattering Performance

CounterPulse provides space and resources for emerging performing artists and cultural innovators, serving as an incubator for the creation of socially relevant, community-based art and culture. Since 1991, we have supported the vanguard of Bay Area performing artists in shattering audience assumptions, creating meaning, and deepening dialogue.

The Little Theater That Could

We weathered the first San Francisco tech boom (and bust), the Great Recession, and in fact, grew our organization when others struggled to survive. History repeats itself, and we find ourselves smack dab in the middle of another tech boom, meaning change is happening fast and space is at a premium. The lease on our current space is up and fortunately we’ve found an affordable new location that just needs some work to become a full-fledged performing arts facility.

A Groundbreaking Moment

We are now at a tipping point where your support can be a catalyst in the success not only of CounterPulse, but of a radical new real-estate development model for arts organizations in the Bay Area and beyond. We’re working with the Community Arts Stabilization Trust (CAST) to renovate a run-down former porn theater and turn it into a vibrant center for art and community. The building will then become a permanent venue for performing artists [seriously, there is a deed restriction on the property for arts and culture use ONLY]. We’re about to break ground and we need your help to make our vision a reality.

Help Us Cross The Finish Line

We’ve raised $1.2 million of the $1.3 million we need to break ground and begin renovations. The money we raise with this Indiegogo campaign will allow to us install much needed lighting, sound, and video equipment in the theater.

Dimmer Packs

$20,000.00

Power source for theatrical lighting

Lighting Accessories

$8,000.00

Hardware for rigging instruments, gels, and gel frames

Audio Speakers

$13,000.00

Surround sound speaker array and power supply

Audio Equipment

$4,000.00

Audio mixer, amp, and power supply

Video & Projection Equipment

$5,000.00

Upgraded projector, control station, associated cables, and adapters

TOTAL

$50,000.00

The Impact

San Francisco is experiencing rapid change. The jobs created by a booming tech sector have attracted many new residents, putting extreme pressure on the real estate market. Nonprofits are losing their spaces and artists are losing their homes. These changes make for uncertain times. Without a concerted effort by local residents to support arts nonprofits, we’re at risk of losing our thriving cultural sector and pushing out the marginalized communities that we’ve long supported.

We need a new model to help stabilize the arts and bolster the resources needed for artists to continue creating in San Francisco. We want to prove that our new model for arts stabilization works.

CounterPulse has a track record of identifying artists who are ready to be appreciated by a larger audience, and have been recognized as a vital incubator of new performance in the Bay Area. In the past year, CounterPulse has supported 2,026 artists in the presentation of 295 events to more than 15,000 audience members. CounterPulse has been named "Best Hybrid Performance Venue” (2007) by the San Francisco Weekly, “Best Performance Space” (2010 & 2013) by the San Francisco Bay Guardian, “Best of Nightlife: Performance Art” (2012) by 7x7 Magazine, “Top Nonprofit” (2010 & 2012) by Philanthropedia and the honored beneficiary of the San Francisco Bay Guardian GOLDIES Awards Party (2014).

This move to a newly renovated building will allow us to increase our impact in the following key areas:

This Will Perk You Up!

To show our gratitude for your support, we've whipped up a fresh design for our CounterPulse T-shirts and totes. These hot items feature the new CounterPulse logo and are on offer to campaign contributors. Select your perk of choice in the right-hand column.

Some of our most beloved partner organizations have been stepping up to show their support for our Indiegogo campaign. And how better show love for CounterPulse than to offer our community enticing perks for joining the campaign, right? We've now got Frameline memberships, Bi-Rite gift cards, Kinetic Arts Center class passes, The Crucible gift certificates, Good Vibrations goodie bags, and Magic Theater Flex Passes available for you generous folk. Get 'em while they last!

Other Ways You Can Help

Don’t have the cash to contribute financially to our campaign? You can still make a difference. Share this campaign with your friends and followers right from Indiegogo by clicking on the links under our campaign video. You can also sign up to participate in visioning events, facilities volunteering (painting, carpentry, etc.), and to help us solicit support.

Words of Support from Our Audiences


We've Been in the News

  • SF Weekly: CounterPulse to Turn Former Porn Theater into Cultural Hub

  • San Francisco Bay Guardian: New pilot program helps arts nonprofits find new homes

  • 7x7: CounterPULSE Gets a New Home

  • KALW Local Public Radio: Your Call: How is the tech boom affecting the arts?

  • Theatre Communications Group: San Francisco’s mid-Market corridor is in rapid transformation. Will the changes jibe with the post-gentrification vision of its performing-arts stakeholders?

  • ABC7 News: Project hopes to help artists stay in San Francisco

  • San Francisco Examiner: Foundation acquires buildings to keep arts in Mid-Market 

  • San Francisco Business Times: Philanthropy Friday: Nonprofit acquires Mid Market, Tenderloin building

  • The Bay Area Reporter: Lee, Kim announce real estate deal to help arts groups 

  • Beyond Chron: Is the Tenderloin turning a corner?

  • San Francisco Arts Quarterly: San Francisco’s Mid-Market Tango

  • Culturebot: Seen and heard in San Francisco

  • San Francisco Bay Guardian: Losing our conscience

  • San Francisco Sentinel: Mayor announces new nonprofit venture to provide permanent homes for arts organizations in Central Market & the Tenderloin

  • San Francisco Arts Commission: SF Arts Commission Awarded Federal Grant to Support Community Arts Stabilization Trust

Media Sponsor:

story:
Natural Steps...

I began my artistic journey on the streets of Atlanta, dashing through the night leaving my mark, and making small attempts to add my aesthetic vision to the landscape. It is only fitting that the next steps on my journey are the cobblestone streets and narrow alleyways of the medieval schist village of Cerdeira, tucked away in the mountains of Portugal. I have been invited by the Cerdeira Village art and crafts council to take part in a two week residency, where I will create temporary and permanent environmental installations throughout the village. This, my friends, is an artistic dream, traveling halfway around the globe to share my vision with another culture. 

(By the Crook, a temporary environmental installation created at the Hambidge Center for the Arts and Sciences, 2014)


It takes a Village...

The Village of Cerdeira has graciously offered living accommodations, a studio containing a wood shop, and technical assistance. Your contributions will help cover travel costs and costs associated with shipping art supplies and materials necessary for the creation of new work. Cerdeira is an isolated village, two and a half hours from the nearest airport, so getting myself there and the materials needed is half the battle. This residency is happening regardless of reaching my funding goals, your support will simply help me enhance both my work and the experience. In exchange for your support, I am offering original art, pieces of Portugal, and even...an installation dedicated to you or your mom, or whomever you choose!

(This is the village of Cerdeira. See what I mean by an artistic dream?)


Dreams...

 Cerdeira Village will be an incredible, life changing experience for me. This will be an important part of my lifetime education as an artist and help me obtain my goal of eventually traveling the world creating art. Residencies are vital to an artist's career, allowing completely uninterrupted time to create, opportunities for new experiences and influences, and a chance to gain recognition on a larger level. This recognition is important to create the sort of opportunities one needs to make bigger and better work. Your contributions and support will help me get further along my path, after all, it is the journey not the destination that is important.

(from the performance "The Nature of Consciousness" 2014 featuring Orion Crook)

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, no problem! There are plenty of other ways you can help: Take a moment to share this campaign on your social media feeds using the share buttons below.
Do you know someone who is an arts supporter, or would like to be? Mention this campaign and point them to this URL:  igg.me/at/krispilcher4
Follow me on Facebook and my website to stay informed about upcoming projects, openings, performances, etc. (links below) Showing up at these events is the best kind of support I can receive!
THANKS!!!!

story:
About Adam!

I'm finally pursuing my dream to become a tattoo wizard and you can help! My name is Adam. I'm a professional hairstylist, musician and visual artist in Portland, OR. I've been working as a stylist for the past 5 years, helping others to feel confident about themselves and the world around them. I value my skills as a compassionate listener and artistic individual. I want to grow into my next phase as a creative caretaker in my community. 

Tattoos are a universal symbol of endurance. They are an exercise in letting go. They are memories and reminders of our own unshakable selves. They are an act of rebellion against the status quo. I want to bring a unique passion into an industry that could benefit from a more vulnerable, empathetic lense.

I want to tattoo you! Yes, you! 

To do this, the first step is for me to attend tattoo school!


Tattoo School?

To become licensed as a tattoo artist in Oregon, you must complete a program from a school accredited by the Oregon Board of Body Art Practitioners. This includes completing coursework on safety, technique, law, as well as practical exams. Based on my portfolio work, I have been accepted into the Forbidden School of Body Art in Portland. You can find out more about the program here: forbiddenbodyart.org

Getting any kind of scholarships or grant money for vocational trade school is difficult to impossible, which is why I'm asking my family and friends and community at large for assistance.

The cost for school runs a total of $12,000. This breaks down as $9,100 for tuition itself, $515 for registration and art supplies such as textbooks and pen sets, and $2,835 for materials such as tattoo machines, inks, and other implements. The initial down payment for school is $7850, which is why I've made my goal $8,000. The rest will be paid with loans. If I go over my goal, additional perks will be unlocked. 


Perks!

Here's a peek at potential perks for your donation! Shipping is included in the price.

For a donation of $10, you'll receive a 2x2" original design die cut sticker! (actual size not shown)

For a donation of $15, you'll receive your choice of one of these three 1.5" buttons! You can choose the $40 package to get all three!


Choose the fourth tier package for $50 to receive: a sticker, choice of button, and my original tattoo zine "FLASH PDX" full of original tattoo designs inspired by Oregon wildlife.




At $50, you can also commission an original pen and ink drawing on 5.5x8.5" gray paper!



I'll have a total of 3 custom painted upcycled vests available at the $100 level! you choose your sizing and design concept, and we'll work together to bring your idea to life in a wearable piece of art!



At the $150 you can receive and actual real life tattoo! Available only to those local to Portland (or those willing to travel).

At this donation level, you will have first pick of one-of-a-kind pre-made designs, choose a design from my art book, or work with me to have a custom design made, then tattooed on your body! Forever! My books will open in the Spring of 2016, and backers will be notified before that time to schedule their appointment.


Additional Perks!

If I go over my goal, I will unlock other perks you can receive! This will include more custom vests, art, and my very own temporary tattoo line!

Thank you!

Thank you so much for your support, even if it's just words of encouragement. If you want to keep up to date with my drawings, I upload most of them to my instagram: http://www.instagram.com/adamponto <3

[you can listen to the full version of the song "Shine On" here: https://soundcloud.com/adam-ponto/shine-on]

story:
Dear Friends

SAVE THE SPACE- at 25 Main!

The School for Contemporary Dance & Thought (SCDT) has joined forces with the Northeast American School of Dance to secure the studio that has been in our community since 1980! You can help save the last remaining large space for dance and theater in Northampton.

Northampton has long been recognized for its progressive outlook and creative enterprise. But with each passing year, the diminishing availability of affordable space for artists endangers that reputation. As countless studies have shown, this trend, if continued, could have social and economic repercussions for our broader community beyond the arts.

Our goal is to get 200 people to

~ Give $20 and get 4 friends to give $20 ~

We have already unexpectedly had to spend almost $10,000 on legal fees and, though we expect to win the case, the fees are expected to reach $15,000 or even $20,000. Right now we are trying to raise $5000  to offset these legal fees.  Any funds collected over and above the legal fees will be spent on much needed improvements to the space."

Scdtnoho.com


Even in recent years, as so many community-oriented arts centers have folded under financial pressure and increasing cuts to public arts funding, 25 Main, with its 4,000 square feet of original, sprung-hardwood floors, has persevered as a rehearsal and performance space for hundreds of people each week. It continues to program classes and events for countless creative entities, including SCDT, Dance Spree, Dance Spirit, Pollinate, Valley Improvisation Dance And Music (VIDAM), Duffy Academy of Irish Dance, West African Dance and Drum, and Lively Dance, among others. See the updated SCDT website for a full list of classes.

For over twenty-five years, the Northeast American School of Dance (NEA) has played a vital role in establishing our town and the broader Pioneer Valley as a beacon for the arts. Under the leadership of Anthony DiVecchi, generations of dancers have trained on the fourth floor of the historic Masonic Block building at 25 Main Street in Northampton.

When the studio’s management recently transferred to the School of Contemporary Dance and Thought (SCDT), it entered an exciting new phase. In addition to preserving and defending its rich tradition, SCDT is revitalizing the studio’s mission with a host of new programs benefiting our community, including dance education for children and adults and professional training for performing artists. It has also embarked on a program of performances, lectures, classes, and panels featuring world renowned, top-caliber artists, with the aim of establishing 25 Main's importance internationally. (A visit to scdtnoho.com reveals that this effort is well underway.)

Now—at this critical juncture in its history—25 Main finds itself in litigation with the landlord, fighting to save its lease. We are confident that our case is strong, but we need your support.


Donations to SCDT can be made through this site or at SCDT support page.

For a tax deductible donation send a check, payable to our fiscal sponsor

“APE Enterprises.” Mail to: SCDT, 25 Main Street suite 444, Northampton MA 01060



The Impact

Northampton has long been recognized for its progressive outlook and creative enterprise. But with each passing year, the diminishing availability of affordable space for artists endangers that reputation. As countless studies have shown, this trend, if continued, could have social and economic repercussions for our broader community beyond the arts.

    The School of Contemporary Dance and Thought﻿ ﻿(SCDT) has been offering classes and curating events since 2013. SCDT is comprised of independent and internationally experienced performance artists/movement practitioners who are also innovative teachers. The goal of SCDT is to serve as a hub for performance art of the highest quality by connecting communities on an local and international scale. SCDT represents contemporary movement training and performance practices that embrace multiplicity, arouse curiosity, and emphasize personal choice. Central to the school’s mission is an abiding respect for the tradition and history of re invention and a directive to continue challenging established ideals. SCDT connects local artists, the five college dance community and an international circuit of performance artists. The roster of featured artists to date includes: Michelle Boule, Nancy Stark Smith, Andrea Olsen, Jennifer Nugent, Miguel Guiterrez, Peter Schmitz, Wendy Perron, Yoshiko Chuma, Chris Aiken, Angie Hauser, Stephanie Maher, Peter Pleyer, Maurice Fraga, Kathy Couch, Sarah Young, Katie Martine, Jake Meginsky, Mike Vargus, Katie Werkum, Joy Davis, Candice Salyers, and Wendy Woodson and more!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, you can still help!

  • Share this campaign and spread the word to your peeps.
  • contact jenscdt@gmail.com to volunteer in the space for events and clean ups

Thank you!

story:
Hello! My name is Kalin and I'm in my last semester at Georgia College & State University. This May I will graduate with a BA in Art, Studio Concentration with a focus in Photography and Digital Media. As an Art major we are required to complete a Capstone project. My Capstone began first semester of Senior year and will end with an exhibition this April. Central to this project is LORE, a magazine I've created featuring small businesses, unique products, and short stories about the people that bring these products to life.

I am starting this funding campaign to allow for the printing of LORE and the sharing of these stories through a community of supporters. My goal is to get LORE into your hands and these stories of vision, inspiration and creativity from Georgia businesses to a wider audience.  Any amount you can give is greatly appreciated. If unable to support financially, you can support by sharing this campaign. Thank you in advance!

Our goal of $900 will be used for the cost of LORE magazine covers, inside pages, and shipping to supporters. For anyone that can give $10, you will receive a copy of LORE magazine. For anyone that can give $15 or more, you will receive your copy of LORE plus a hand-printed, limited edition screen print of the magazine cover. For $25 or more, you will receive 2 copies of LORE plus a screen print. For $50 or more, you will receive 4 copies of LORE plus 2 screen prints. Please join us for the 5:00 PM opening exhibition reception at Ennis Hall on April 14, 2016.

All magazines will be shipped by May 11.  Thank you for your support!

story:
Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina


The heart of Southeastern Europe and part of the former Yugoslavia, Bosnia and Herzegovina declared independence in 1992. This was followed by 3.5 years of violent wars which ended in 1995. Twenty-five years later, there are still visible scars on the landscape and the people of this small but vibrant community. Today, Mostar is home to a UNESCO World Heritage Site and is a growing tourist destination. The town and its surroundings have an unmistakable natural beauty that fosters the strong attachment of local residents as well as the travelers who have the opportunity to visit. Despite this, Mostar in 2019 is still deeply segregated and struggling to heal from the violence that ripped apart the once highly integrated community.


Mostar Street Arts Festival


The Street Arts Festival Mostar was developed by a local residents in 2012. They wanted to create an arts based project that was inclusive – bringing together local and international artists, volunteers, and visitors to work together to revitalize Mostar's public space and infuse it with positive energy. Over the last 8 years, the Street Arts Festival has grown to attract world-class street artists alongside emerging young local artists to contribute to the tranformation of the urban space into an outdoor art gallery which can be enjoyed by all. Previously the canvas for messages of intolerance and hate, the artwork has the ability to re-story neighborhoods, parks and abandoned spaces with narratives of beauty, inclusivity, and dynamism. To date, over 100 murals have been incorporated in the fabric of Mostar. While the Street Art Festival responds to the events of the past, it is very much a movement of the present, which looks toward a more promising future for Mostar and its residents and offers a new attraction for international visitors to the region.

You Make it Possible!


The Street Arts Festival Mostar is organized and implemented by a group of highly motivated local and international voluneteers. This group dedicates their time and energy to the realization of the Street Arts Festival each year alongisde the artists in residence who participate in the transformation of Mostar's public space. While our passion is unlimited, the Street Arts Festival Mostar is largely dependent on the contributions made by both local community members and organizations well as international donors. We need your help!


Your donations will ensure that the Street Arts Festival Mostar will be able to continue to support the local and international artists that will participate in the 8th Annual Mostar Street Arts Festival from September 1st – 9th, 2019. Your donations will cover the cost of the resources the artists need to create their work, including paint, scaffolding, and elevators as well as basic accommodation, food, and transportation during their stay. We hope to surpass our fundraising goal, but if we do not all donations will still be put toward the implementation of the Street Arts Festival Mostar. The more donations that we receive, the more artists we can invite to participate in the Street Arts Festival Mostar this year!


Even if you cannot donate, you can still support our initiative! We invite you to share our campaign by word of mouth and on any social media platforms.

 

Become a Volunteer!

The Street Arts Festival can always use an extra pair of helping hands both before and during the festival. Are you an artist? Like to meet new and interesting people? Want to get experience putting on large events and festivals? Join us in making this festival happen! 


Current Schedule


In addition to the murals that will be added to Mostar's outdoor gallery this year, we will be hosting and supporting the creation of art-based events for all ages during the Street Arts Festival Mostar. These events are intended to be inclusive, inviting the entire community to participate, attend and enjoy musical performances, workshops, and exhibits that take place in the public spaces that the Street Arts Festival Mostar serves. We will continue to update you as additional artists are added to this year's roster and events promoting and supporting the Street Arts movement are developed and scheduled. During the festival will be organized OFF programs like : first solo exhibitions by local artists, book promotions, performances, workshops and music programs.

Check out our Facebook page for the latest news!
